terms.definition: A ceiling rose with three terminal blocks: Loop (permanent live group), Neutral group, and Switched Live group to the lamp.
The terminal group where the supply Line and the switch feed (to COM) are connected together.
The conductor returning from the switch (from L1) that becomes live only when the switch is ON.
Circuit Protective Conductor; maintains the earth path through the circuit for safety.

content.title: The Systematic Build Flow (and how you prove it safely)
content.content:
Safety note (training rig only): This lesson is for supervised training-rig work in an approved dead state. Do not energise equipment. Do not work on real installations.

A one-way lighting circuit (3-plate ceiling rose) is only as good as (1) build quality and (2) the reliability of your test routine. Beginners improve fastest when they follow the same sequence every single time.

## Step 0 — Rig-safe start
Confirm the rig is in its approved dead state. Identify the correct circuit before touching any conductors.

## Step 1 — Plan from the diagram (wire-journey check)
Before you cut/strip anything, you must be able to point to the diagram and say:
- Which terminal group is the **Loop (permanent live)**.
- Which conductor is the **switch feed** (Rose Loop → switch COM).
- Which conductor is the **switch return / switched live** (switch L1 → Rose Switched Live).
- Where the **Neutral group** joins supply neutral + lamp neutral.
- Where the **CPC** is terminated at every point.

## Step 2 — Mount accessories
Fix the rose/batten holder and the switch accessory neatly. Covers must fit without crushing conductors.

## Step 3 — Route and prepare cables
- Bring the **sheath into every accessory** (no single-insulated cores exposed outside).
- Identify at the ends (don’t leave it ambiguous):
  - CPC: green/yellow sleeving where required.
  - Any core used as **live** in the switch drop: **brown identification** at terminations (especially the return if a blue core is used).

## Step 4 — Terminate (follow the 3-plate map)
- **Loop group:** CU Line + switch feed to COM.
- **Neutral group:** CU Neutral + lamp neutral.
- **Switched Live group:** switch return from L1 + lamp live.
- **CPC:** continuous and terminated at each point (including the switch point).

## Step 5 — Dead inspection (decision gate)
You only proceed if inspection is a PASS.
Stop-and-fix examples (don’t ignore): exposed copper, damaged insulation, CPC missing/unterminated, insulation clamped in terminal (“plastic-in”), loose terminations.

## Step 6 — Dead tests + recording (rig-safe)
Your goal here is NOT to energise anything. It’s to confirm the circuit is safe and ready for results recording and the next supervised stage.

### Dead Test Routine (must be used)
For each test:
1) **Prove** the tester/function/leads (known condition)
2) **Test** the circuit
3) **Re-prove** the tester/function/leads
4) **Record** the value + judgement (Pass / Suspicious / Stop-and-check)

Typical dead tests for this exercise (training rig context):
- **CPC continuity (low-ohms)** to confirm the protective path is present and continuous.
- **Insulation Resistance (IR)** between conductors to confirm no unwanted leakage paths.
- **Polarity logic (dead method)** to confirm the switch is in the line conductor and the correct terminals/groups are used.

Common beginner mistake to avoid: recording a weird reading without first checking the tester setup. If the result surprises you, your first move is usually: check range, ports, leads, nulling (if used), and repeat Prove → Test → Re-prove.

content.title: Check Your Understanding: Terminal Groups + Tests

questions.questionText: Which terminal group in the ceiling rose connects the permanent live from the CU to the switch feed?
questions.hint: It stays live when the switch is OFF (if energised).

questions.questionText: What colour identification must be applied to a blue core that is used as a switched live (switch return)?
questions.hint: Any core used as live must be identified as live at the ends.

questions.questionText: Which dead test checks there is no unwanted leakage path between conductors (e.g., Line and Neutral)?
When the switch is OFF, what is the practical difference between the Loop group and the Switched Live group?
questions.expectedAnswer: The Loop group is the permanent live join/feed, but the Switched Live group should not be live when the switch is OFF because it only becomes live when COM connects to L1.
questions.hint: One is permanent feed; one depends on switch position.

content.title: Worked Example: Recording Dead Test Results (Beginner-Friendly)
content.given: A student has completed a one-way lighting circuit on a training rig and performed CPC continuity and IR tests. (Example fields and example values.)

steps.description: Write down the tester type and any ID your results sheet expects (e.g., instrument name, serial number if required).
steps.result: Instrument: MFT (example). ID/Serial: as required by the results sheet.

steps.description: CPC continuity (low-ohms): confirm the correct function/range and null/zero leads if your procedure requires it, then record the reading.
Insulation resistance (IR): set the test voltage specified by your rig procedure, perform Prove → Test → Re-prove, then record the reading(s).
steps.result: IR readings: L–N: >999 MΩ, L–CPC: >999 MΩ, N–CPC: >999 MΩ (example over-range).

steps.description: Write a short comment that links the result to the build quality (simple and professional).
steps.result: Comment: "Dead inspection PASS, CPC continuous, IR high/acceptable. Ready for results recording." (example).

content.notes: Example values are for learning only. Always follow the rig procedure sheet for what to test, where to test, and what to record.

content.title: Guided Practice: Build Flow (Aligned to Steps 0–6)
content.problem: You are about to build and dead-test a one-way lighting circuit on a training rig. Follow the flow and answer each step before moving on.

steps.prompt: Step 0 (Rig-safe start): What must be confirmed about the rig BEFORE you touch any conductors?
expectedAnswer: Rig is in an approved dead state
steps.hint: This is the gate before any work begins.

steps.prompt: Step 1 (Plan): Name the two switch terminals used in a one-way switch for this circuit.
steps.hint: Input is COM, output is L1.

steps.prompt: Step 4 (Terminate): Which ceiling rose terminal group does the switch feed connect into?
steps.hint: This is the permanent live join/feed group.

steps.prompt: Step 4 (Terminate): Which ceiling rose terminal group must the lamp live connect into?
steps.hint: This keeps the lamp controlled by the switch.

steps.prompt: Step 5 (Dead inspection): Name ONE 'stop-and-fix' issue that would make you stop before using meters.
Step 6 (Dead test routine): What is the correct order of the routine that makes readings trustworthy?

options.text: Connect Supply Line to Loop terminal
Connect Switch Feed to Loop terminal
Connect Switched Live to Loop terminal

content.explanation: The Switched Live has its own terminal group; Loop is for permanent live.

questions.questionText: In a 3-plate rose, which two conductors share the Neutral terminal group?
questions.hint: Neutral joins at the rose; it is not switched.

questions.questionText: You are about to do an IR test. What should you write for the test voltage if you are following the correct beginner behaviour?
questions.hint: This is a 'lookup' behaviour check: don’t guess the value.

questions.questionText: True or False: CPC identification/sleeving only matters if the backbox is metal.
questions.hint: Identification matters at terminations so the function is clear.

questions.questionText: You get an unexpected test result that does not match your circuit map. What is your safest next action BEFORE concluding the circuit is wrong?
expectedAnswer: Check tester setup and repeat Prove → Test → Re-prove
Re-prove the tester, check leads/ports/range, then re-test
Verify settings/leads then re-test using prove test re-prove
questions.hint: Remove tester/leads/settings as the hidden cause first.

questions.question: Which terminal connects Supply Line and switch feed?
What state must the rig be in before touch?
What is the three-step routine for using testers?
How many terminal blocks are in the rose?
Is visual checking called inspection or testing?

questions.questionText: Connection (Level 2): If the switch is OFF, which terminal group should still be a 'permanent feed' group and which should NOT be feeding the lamp? Explain in 1–2 sentences using the group names.
questions.expectedAnswer: The Loop group is the permanent feed/join group (it remains the permanent feed group), but the Switched Live group should not be feeding the lamp when the switch is OFF because COM is not connected to L1.
questions.hint: Use: Loop group vs Switched Live group, and OFF means COM not connected to L1.

questions.questionText: Synthesis (Level 3): Explain why a dead inspection must happen before meter testing, and how Prove → Test → Re-prove protects you from recording a false result. (3–4 sentences, beginner language).
questions.expectedAnswer: Dead inspection finds obvious problems (like exposed copper, loose wires, insulation trapped in terminals, or missing CPC) that can make testing unsafe or make readings meaningless. Prove → Test → Re-prove checks that the tester and leads are working before and after you test, so you can trust the reading. If a result looks strange, you’re less likely to blame the circuit when the real problem is the meter setup. This helps you record results that are safe and reliable.
questions.hint: Think: physical safety first, then instrument reliability.

content.title: Spaced Review

questions.questionText: From 204-11B: What does Prove → Test → Re-prove protect you from?
questions.expectedAnswer: False results caused by tester/leads/settings faults or incorrect setup.
questions.hint: It checks the instrument and leads before and after.

questions.questionText: From 204-12A: Name two items on a dead inspection checklist for a lighting circuit.
questions.expectedAnswer: No exposed copper; tight terminations (tug test); sheath inside accessory; CPC present and terminated; no insulation clamped in terminal.
questions.hint: Any two safety/quality checks are fine.

questions.questionText: From 204-11C: Why might you need to null/zero leads before low-ohms testing?
questions.expectedAnswer: To remove the resistance of the test leads so the reading reflects the circuit, not the leads.

questions.questionText: From 204-14A: Which conductor must the switch break in a one-way lighting circuit?
questions.hint: The switch interrupts the live path, not the neutral.

content.notes: Reinforcing inspection-first logic, instrument trust, and the one-way wire journey.
